facts.text: On April 15, 1942, Radhabai (plaintiff) entrusted gold, pearl and diamond jewellery of the value of Rs. 32,379/6/- to Lachhmi Narain for safe custody.
Lachhmi Narain, father of Sitaram (appellant), was the brother of Radhabai (plaintiff).
Lachhmi Narain died in July 1943.
After death of Lachhmi Narain, plaintiff called upon appellant Sitaram to return the jewellery; appellant replied that it had been returned by Lachhmi Narain during his lifetime on April 23, 1942.
Plaintiff instituted suit in Court of First Civil Judge, Kanpur against Sitaram, his son Ghanshyam (minor) and other family members for delivery of jewellery or payment of value.
Trial Court dismissed the suit, upholding appellant's case that jewellery was returned on April 23, 1942, relying on receipt Ext. A-4 (held genuine by Trial Court).

Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 162 of 1947 reversed Trial Court decree on July 18, 1961, directing restoration of jewellery within one month or payment of Rs. 32,379/6/- with costs by appellant and Ghanshyam out of Lachhmi Narain's estate.
Ghanshyam, minor at material times, died unmarried during pendency of High Court appeal; his name struck off.
Appellant received telegram from Lachhmi Narain on April 20, 1942; plaintiff and her son-in-law Radha Kishen proceeded to Kanpur and remained till April 23, 1942.
Steel box in which jewellery taken from Jhansi to Kanpur was with plaintiff even at trial.
Plaintiff sent some jewellery to daughter Shyamabai via letter Ext. A-2 (undated, admitted by plaintiff); list includes some items similar to those entrusted to Lachhmi Narain.
Plaintiff did not make demand for jewellery during lifetime of Lachhmi Narain or for two years thereafter.

Plaintiff proceeded to Kanpur on telegram about broken padlock of her house at Rail Bazar, Kanpur; returned to Jhansi by evening train on April 23, 1942, leaving empty steel box (jewellery handed in baskets).
Testimony of Dr. Mohan Lal (treated plaintiff on April 22-23, 1942 at Jhansi) and dispensary record held unreliable by Trial Court.
Radha Charan (who carried jewellery to Shyamabai) not examined; testimony of Banwari Lal (Shyamabai's husband) against appellant's case.
Oral demands made after Lachhmi Narain's death (see lawyer's notice Ext. 24).
Ram Sewak (plaintiff's son) died November 1941, leaving widow Gomtibai; disputes arose, referred to arbitration.

During arbitration pendency, on advice of Lachhmi Narain (defendant Nos. 1 to 7), plaintiff deposited jewellery with him for safety due to dispute with Gomtibai and political movement; got writing from Shyania Charan and Priya Charan.
Gomtibai did not claim the ornaments; not considered in arbitration award.
Receipt Ext. A-4 held not genuine by Trial Court and High Court.
Lachhmi Narain and appellant members of joint Hindu family governed by Mitakshara law.

legal_issues.text: Whether the jewellery was returned to the plaintiff by Lachhmi Narain on April 23, 1942.
Whether the suit is maintainable given the entrustment was to defraud Gomtibai, invoking in pari delicto potior est conditio defendentis.
Whether appellant liable out of joint family estate for debt arising from misappropriation, as avyavaharika or illegal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Jewellery returned on April 23, 1942, proved by circumstances: presence in Kanpur till 23rd per telegram April 20; steel box with plaintiff; Ext. A-2 to daughter with similar items; no demand during lifetime or 2 years after.
Suit not maintainable as entrustment to defraud Gomtibai (per plaint paras 5-6); parties in pari delicto potior est conditio defendentis.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: in pari delicto potior est conditio defendentis

petitioner_arguments.text: No liability on joint family property for avyavaharika/illegal debt from misappropriation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Toshanpal Singh Ors. v. District Judge of Agra Ors.; Hindu law (Mitakshara)

respondent_arguments.text: Jewellery entrusted April 15, 1942, not returned; went to Kanpur for broken padlock, returned same evening with empty box; receipt not genuine.
Gomtibai knew of entrustment; no illegal purpose pleaded; not in pari delicto; fiduciary duty of Lachhmi Narain.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ansons Principles of the English Law of Contracts

court_reasoning.text: Receipt Ext. A-4 not genuine (agrees with High Court); circumstances do not prove return: presence in Kanpur on 23rd does not infer receipt; empty box explained; Ext. A-2 similarity common, not proved sent after return; no demand not significant due to confidence; oral demands post-death.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Circumstances taken individually or collectively do not make out the case of the appellant.

court_reasoning.text: No proper pleading or issue on fraud; Trial Judge determined non-arising issue; not in pari delicto: Gomtibai knew per plaint; exceptions apply (illegal purpose not carried out against Gomtibai, fiduciary duty, no reliance on illegality); plaintiff persuaded by Lachhmi Narain under fiduciary duty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Where parties not in pari delicto, less guilty party may recover; fiduciary cannot retain on illegality plea.

court_reasoning.text: Debt not proved avyavaharika/illegal; no evidence of misappropriation by Lachhmi Narain; Toshanpal Singh distinguished as that involved criminal breach of trust.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sons liable for father's debts unless avyavaharika/illegal; burden on appellant not discharged.

holdings.text: Jewellery not returned; appellant fails to prove return.
Suit maintainable; in pari delicto does not apply due to lack of plea, knowledge of Gomtibai, fiduciary duty.
Joint family estate liable; debt not avyavaharika/illegal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Toshanpal Singh Ors. v. District Judge of Agra Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Does not support contention that joint family not liable for misappropriation debt, as no proof of criminal breach of trust here.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Law (Mitakshara)
statutes_cited.relevance: Sons liable for father's debts unless avyavaharika/illegal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court agrees with High Court, rejects all contentions of appellant, upholds decree for restoration of jewellery within one month or payment of Rs. 32,379/6/- with costs out of Lachhmi Narain's estate in hands of appellant.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of jewellery or payment of value with costs.
outcome.costs: With costs as per High Court decree.

key_quotes.text: "The circumstances taken either individually or collectively do not make out the case of the appellant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects proof of return of jewellery.

key_quotes.text: "It was the plaintiffs case that it was at the persuation of Lachhmi Narain that the jewellery was entrusted to him. Again on the plaintiffs case Lachhmi Narain was under a fiduciary duty to the plaintiff."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why in pari delicto does not bar recovery.

key_quotes.text: "There is no evidence to prove that the debt was avyavaharika or illegal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
